utterances: One of the primary objectives of this whole exercise is to get you to understand that you and your employees, are the only ones who could make that assessment.
He says employees should be encouraged to report their concerns without, of course, getting hysterical every time someone leaves a bag on a bus.
He says most of it's just common sense, which someday could prove crucial.
Pam Fessler, NPR News.
The news this week that GM was shutting down plants and cutting some 30,000 jobs was another blow to the labor movement.
Labor has seen its influence decline as the number of union workers--once one in three--has declined to less than 10 percent of the work force.
One labor leader determined to reverse that downward spiral is Andrew Stern.
He's president of the Service Employees International Union.
He leads a group of unions that broke away from the AFL-CIO earlier this year.
Stern says GM's woes are part of a larger problem that the whole country needs to face: the high cost of health care and the burden it places on both employees and employers.
Yes, good afternoon, Ira.
I love your show.
This came up in a discussion we had with musician David Was, who was at last week's Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas.
He told us about a record player, the Ion ITTUSB Turntable.
It has a USB port that connects to your PC.
So you can make digital copies of your old LPs.
Right.
And it comes with software that helps eliminate some of the scratches and pops on those old recordings, which David Was noted is ironic since record producers now often add hiss and pops.
`What?
asks Paige Gold(ph) of Los Angeles.
`Why would producers do that?'
For the answer, we return to our Mr. Was.
Just like there's a vogue for distressing fabrics and surfaces of furniture to make it look old, producers in the hip-hop world want to add that imperfection to make things seem authentically funky.
Musician and DAY TO DAY contributor David Was.
Thanks to all of you who wrote us and please keep sending us your comments.

After a week that was all Iraq all the time, health care is back on the agenda, more specifically, Hillary care.
President Bush settles on his pick for Attorney General.
MoveOn.org feels betrayed, again, this time by Rudy Giuliani, who fires back.
America's mayor also plans to join several other Republican presidential hopefuls to address the National Riffle Association on Friday.

Ken Rudin joins us, our own Political Junkie, NPR's political editor with us as usual here in Studio 3A.
Hey, Ken.
Hi, Neal.
And why don't we start with the president's announcement this week, the nomination of Michael Mukasey to be his third Attorney General.
Mukasey is a compromise of sorts, isn't he?
Well, in a sense that although the media had been focusing on Ted Olsen, the former solicitor general whom Bush reportedly would have liked to have nominated.
Harry Reid, the democratic senator, majority leader, said early on that there's no way the Senate is going to confirm Ted Olsen.
And, of course, the White House insists they didn't pull back on Olsen for that reason, but they did want somebody confirmed quickly, and Mukasey looks like he's the guy.
Yet, the Democrats still hope to use the nomination, hold it up until the White House comes across with a lot of the documentation that the Senate has been seeking in its investigation.
Right.
A lot of investigations, mostly on the firing of the U.S.
attorneys and, you know, the procedures for the treatment of terror suspects.
So there are a lot of questions that the Democrats and the Congress has for the Justice Department and those were some of the questions they'd like to ask during the confirmation hearing.
And Iraq certainly did not go away this week.

Just yesterday, the president hosted an event in the Rose Garden of the White House with military families gathered around to listen to him lobby for what he calls General Petraeus' plan or it might even be his plan.
(Soundbite of President Bush's speech)
General Petraeus came back to the United States to deliver the recommendations he made to me.

Inherent in his recommendations is, one, his belief we're succeeding, his belief we will succeed, and I asked the United States Congress to support the troop levels and the strategies I have embraced.
(Soundbite of applause)
And that was followed by chants of USA, USA.
This, of course, a carefully selected audience of military families.
Nevertheless, the Democrats have decided thus far, as I understand it, on just one piece of legislation that they're hoping to pass that might restrict the number of troops in Iraq.
Right.
But the Democratic prospects of victory look less and less hopeful for them as the days go on.

Jim Webb, the freshman senator from Virginia has proposed that if you spend 15 months - if a serviceman or a woman spends 15 months in Iraq then they should be able to spend 15 months or the same amount of time at home.
And they, probably, they were - when they had that vote in July, they were three votes short of gaining the 60 votes they needed to proceed.
John Warner, the respected and retiring Republican from Virginia, was talking about perhaps backing this rare proposal.
But after consultation with Defense Secretary Gates and listening to the administration folks, he's backing away from that.
They feel, the Republicans are now saying that it should be the military, not the Democratic Congress, should decide how long these people are employed in Iraq.

The question is whether the alleged victim is just another example of a black woman who's engaged in certain kind of sexual behavior, and what was she doing there as a stripper, and is she a respectable person just because of who she is.
But I think--and also, the idea that men can take advantage of black women and get away with it, which was a historical phenomenon, which is true still today, more often than not.
But I wanted to point out also, Farai, that we don't know if Duke is being a good citizen in Durham, but the question is raised because of this.
Also, we don't know yet that--whether the prosecutor will, in fact, bring charges or not.
What we heard was what the defense lawyers said.
The defense lawyers said that, therefore, nothing happened because of the DNA.
We don't know what the prosecutor will say, and we have all these questions about--what was her physical condition?
And what did the physician say?
So, before we absolutely conclude that she is Tawana Brawley, we should keep in mind that context.
But even if it turns out that the story is not true, the behavior of the guys in that group, what kind of culture is existing there in Durham?
And what is the Duke University tolerating among its students?
These are still important questions to raise.
Yeah, I don't think that...
